review_title: Incorporar una persona con una formación y experiencia profesional de calidad e idónea
pros:
Por que este postulante a través del trabajo con equipos de reingeniería, construcción y servicios multidisciplinarios; ha logrado vencer las dificultades propias de toda negociación o desarrollo comercial. Tales como rutas críticas, estacionalidades de venta, quiebres de stock, almacenes particulares (flujo de caja), nuevos productos, estudios del mercado, comparación con la competencia, retroalimentación de los resultados y aplicar medidas correctivas; todo en el entorno de ofrecer al cliente un compromiso con su negocio.

Mostrar que hacer planes de trabajo, fortalecer e integrar las habilidades técnicas, profesionales, experiencia de trabajo, técnicas nuevas en beneficio de la operación. Mostrar y Traspasar a el entorno que hacer un trabajo bien hecho generará una satisfacción personal, laboral, familiar y social.
Establecer que uno como parte de una empresa quiere generar un lazo de servicios, una empatía, conocer las inquietudes intereses y objetivos del cliente para a través de esta diferencia mostrar las otras diferencias del producto o servicio que se requiere usar y optimizar.
cons: Me resulta difícil en algunas ocasiones mejorar el desbalance entre la vida personal y laboral; Mejorar la relación con pares y hacer que no sea una competencia sino que sea un aprendizaje; Buscar más el equilibrio de género por el aporte importante de otro punto de vista, que la motivación sea un trabajo en conjunto no solo esperar sino que aportar ideas y así generar desarrollo profesional. No dejar de plantear la transparencia de responsabilidades, compromisos, evaluaciones en el área de salarios coherentes con las funciones.

The current senior team pushes Amazon Leadership Principles downward, using their interpretation (not the corporate one) to manipulate lower managers to manage Associates in a sort of slave labor mode. They violate employment contracts of middle managers without regard to achievement or success those middle managers deliver. They reward those who laugh at their jokes and cut up with them over those who produce measurable results.

job_title: Customer Care in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
I actually really thought that Pillpack does really well with their employees, Working for Amazon as a parent company had good Employee benefits as well as Pillpack Benefits, I have special needs and I felt like the company really worked well with those needs and accommodations
Starting wage for this position now is 16 per hour, however those who were here before the Amazon Buyout got a dollar pay bump
This company doesn't fire people easily, which can be seen as a pro and con, I had many coworkers(Older, and I apologize if this offends any readers but, "Boomer" is the most accurate type of description) who were too stubborn with technology and business practices with new technologies often messing up or not paying attention to training and messing up consistently (I personally reported on other agents working returned tickets and sending tickets back for training or reporting potential inappropriate medical messups at least once a week for a few of these people)
The pay is good and it can be a fun place to work, (I am posting this as a current employee with mainly heath issues causing me to search elsewhere)
cons:
There were occasional mishaps with rude Supervisors/Managers/Team Leads or inappropriate team mates as pretty much any other jobs will have
however it is difficult with part time hours to move up or to other departments
often they come up with new plans for advancement but management is too overloaded to work with agents individually on certifying training for pay increases
There are peak buisness times of year such as open enrollment and insurance new year, tax season, and new medication launches which causes stress on agents and call queue
Often times we are told Customers first, however must meet specific quota with time and work, some tasks can take up to an hour, and that is company wide understood, however must have an avg of 10 minutes, When working part time hours this is difficult if you work peak business times and have 3 or 4 of those calls per week, (Or day if you had my luck) when catching other peoples mistakes or being efficient for customers medical needs this ends up ruining your stats, making it almost impossible for advancement or switching to other departments

pros: Being an Area Manager for Amazon, AMZL specifically, is not a bad job like everyone makes it out to be. I have met a plethora of wonderful people who really do care about the people part and not just the numbers. Amazon does care about metrics a lot, and you will feel that pressure, but a good leader will help you navigate through it. Amazon is a challenging environment that pushes you to grow REALLY quickly, especially if this is your first job. You can learn a years worth of knowledge in a month and the pay is decent for what you're doing, especially when getting promoted. Amazon is also very people focused especially towards the normal associates. It is hard work but Amazon takes a lot of steps to ensure that they feel valued. The only thin that gets in the way of that is us managers who don't know how to engage them in the right ways, This isn't a job for everyone though, it takes a lot of dedication and you have to be able to push past your normal limits. As tough as it can be, it is still very rewarding.
cons: Amazon moves very fast. You can be gone for three days and everything has changed. Because of the pace, some things get lost in translation and you have to figure out how to deal with new situations all the time. The Amazon network overall has tight control of things that sometimes don't make sense to the stations such as HC. This can put you in odd situations where you have to figure demands from the network. The metric focus is heavy and you're constantly trying top figure out how to help people achieve their rates which can be tough. This role asks a lot of you all of the time and you will feel it. It isn't overwhelming when you get used to it but it still can be a lot. If you're considering this role, just be mindful of trying to separate work life from home life and keep yourself in check.

review_title: Don't come here if you're young
pros: Personal growth. Being at Amazon definitely toughened me and taught me to persevere through adversity. You see the good and bad about corporate work culture, which for a young person can be very valuable. People are a mixed bag, but I'm still extremely close with a former team of brilliant minds I was placed in. It's very much the luck of the draw who you'll get. Also, very fun work trips on Bezos' dime.
cons: A lot of piecewise processes, and for the specific role very monotonous and boring work. In some respects, we were socialized away from listening to data to instead build personal capital during business review meetings around "instinct". Abusive culture. Everyone has an agenda, and even when I was identified as a "top performer" I was manipulated into a new role that in reality required a lot less skill and creativity. Extremely political, and even if you try to steer clear of it you'll be seen as unengaged. Sometimes management and coworkers seem so focused on the promotion or their next rotation that they don't even consider collaboration or building rapport or genuine connection with coworkers. People were constantly moving around on the team, and thus others are constantly overburdened with residual work and responsibilities. Side projects really only fly if it's going to make a manager look good, not just because of personal curiosity or a desire for development. I had a manager tell me I could not attend specific trainings because although infrequent they were during our weekly business review, even though he knew it was a subject I had an interest in (and now have a successful career in). Amazon takes a very laissez faire approach to corporate culture, which is why this sort of manipulation can take place. This same manager also took my words out of context to bully me into following his agenda, and there's really no recourse for handling these sorts of situations within the company.

pros: It was not good at all
cons: Everything i consider a con

pros:
There is opportunity within the company, even at the level of working in their fulfilment centers. 

Experienced employees, specifically the line managers (I don't know what to fall them because there's no real title stated), can be very helpful. 

They offer lots of resources to help you help yourself.
cons:
Know your limits before you choose your shift because you won't find that out until after you start working and you'll choose your shift hours even before that. 

It can be nearly impossible to change shift hours, even with accomodations. 

Communication between departments is almost non-existent, especially with HR. 

If you have a question about some process, HR will direct you to management. If management doesn't know they'll redirect you to HR. 

Management structure is almost non-existent or inconsistent. I never met a direct manager outside of the floor crew and half the time I was never told or made aware of who is in charge of what. I also reported to a different person almost everyday on the same shift doing the same work.

You're in charge of your hours, but they tell you when to clock in and leave. You have to jump through hoops if they need you to work over, but you have a standing appointment. 

It's At-Will employment, so the possiblity of getting fired for the smallest thing will always hang over your head.

Training is lacking. Beyond the most simply task, no one knew well enough of their responsibilities, even those who have been there for a while.

review_title: Best job I've ever had, amazing place to grow
job_title: Product Design Engineer in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
There's a real passion here for the work we do that I enjoy immensely, and so much freedom to operate even at the lowest level. My manager (and I understand that I lucked out and not all managers are as good) doesn't micromanage but points me in the right direction so I can exercise my judgement.


My coworkers are all intimidatingly smart and always willing to help, and so are the cross functional teams (PM, TPMS, other system owners). The re's specific structures set up for new engineers to learn and it helps immensely. At my last job I feel like I was not really treated as a human being, but here I operate free of stress even when there's deadlines to meet

The company's also been super accommodating during the pandemic about working from home and enabling us to still be able to function well.
cons: Apparently The pay isn't as high as Google or Apple? though I'm fine with it. I don't really have any other comparable frame of reference and I can make rent and save for retirement so to me it's fair

review_title: Your experience depends on the team
job_title: Principal Product Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Smart colleagues, exciting work, potential to continue to be good. Exciting in tech space.
cons: Every Amazonian does the work of two employees at other companies . Work 4 years , vest stock and leave. Promotion process is like getting a Christmas gift. You are not supposed to know until after whether you were considered or not. You can work towards the promotion for an entire year and someone in the room can ask “this is not scoped at the level “ and you are done . What modern company promotes this way ? Why is there such a need for secrecy? Manager can play favorites and promote their favorites and HR won’t even intervene. The second stock prices start dropping , there will be a mass exodus . If you are not in a good team immediately switch. Don’t linger. When all other companies are going to WFH, Amazon now requires roles to be associated to a physical office.

review_title: This company (AWS) can‘t be ranked as a top employer although it is leading the market leader.
pros: Good salary, good benefits, some kind folks working there.
cons:
No one cares about the well being of employees, nothing being done more than useless statements and deco principles. Some people, incl. account managers, are pushed to meet customers during Covid-19 with blatant disregard to human wellbeing. During 3 years of work, I have seen a lot of good people being terminated after they start, just because there manager think they don‘t fit, even if the manager is still new to AWS and to the cloud. A lot of people are being hired with no good culture being maintained, many people would just leave if they get a higher offer. Mixed feeling about working there, but I wouldn‘t do it again.
So many slogans and principles flying around, it becomes ironic after a while how you see some people violating basic ethics in treating employees while repeating Amazon Principles all the time.

review_title: Too big for their own pants
pros: Good opportunity for a career and lots of money....they will throw money at you if you are an outsider. People seem nice at first..If you are ok with sacrificing all of your personal time and perhaps even shedding a few years off your lifespan, this place is fantastic. Also, the company is diverse...so diverse it often feels like diversity is being prescribed...truly groundbreaking.
cons:
The majority of employees are indifferent at best, and frustrated in general. Very high turnover, Senior managers and GM catering to corporate instead of listening to the teams. Crazy and unnecessary non-value-added tasks daily and no willingness or attempt to develop their new supervisors. Everything is based on "the customer" no matter what...to the extent of losing thousands of dollars per minute...The golden handcuffs that are offered to managers should be illegal as it requires them to pay back upwards of $100,000 if they quit before their contract is up. This is also not explained nor is there any breakdown of these costs when one quits....as if the number is made up or something. Senior managers are experts at gaslighting. If you do well, they let you know you are on thin ice and that you have to work harder. Their objective review process is not objective at all and does not review anything. Just another good-ol' boy system disguised as a diverse and inclusive workplace. If you can work somewhere else, you should and avoid Amazon at all costs. There is a good reason they have a bad rap in the media.

Biggest gripe: the leadership pronciples are lip service and often used as weapons or reasons for justifying bad leadership. Specifically, innovation. The management team is not interested in innovation, even when a simple and cheap to implement idea is proven to save hundreds of millions of dollars in time and money, something I can personally attest to and have several examples of. The very principles that founded the company are now nowhere to be found and that is sad.
